newsitem.title: USA: Pan Am expects to fly this month after merger vote.
newsitem.headline: Pan Am expects to fly this month after merger vote.

text.p: Pan American World Airways said Wednesday it planned to resume flying this month following a merger agreement that will provide key financing for the airline.
Panam said Frost Hanna Mergers Group Inc. of Boca Raton, Fla., agreed to merge with Pan Am and create Pan Am Corp.

"We would expect to consummate the merger and be in the air this month," it said. "Frost Hanna's involvement provides Pan Am with an additional $10 million in cash and is a key part of the $40 million financing we have raised to launch a serious, high quality airline."
Pan Am and Frost Hanna had announced the proposed merger in January.
Pan Am said the new entity would likely become a publicly traded company listed on the American Stock Exchange.
The airline, temporarily headquartered in Miami, said it would begin service with A300 Airbus wide-bodied aircraft with daily flights serving New York, Miami and Los Angeles.
It would later add San Francisco, Chicago and San Juan during the first year of operation, it said.
The previous Pan Am, one of the world's aviation pioneers, collapsed in 1991 under heavy debts.
Two years later, Florida businessmen Chuck Cobb and Martin Shugrue bought its name and logo with the intent of eventually resurrecting the airline.
